info.game_comments:
2005 Ultimate Tournament of Champions Round 1, game 26.
Audio signaling system in play in sync with the game board lights.

(1, 1).clue: Just months after becoming the Duchess of Aquitaine, she became the Queen of France

(2, 1).clue: One of Lucille Ball's favorite episodes was when she & Ethel got jobs in this kind of kitchen & couldn't keep up

(3, 1).clue: Emeril puts bacon, leeks & chunks of potatoes in his Fall River version of this New England soup

(4, 1).clue: He was the 41st vice president of the U.S.

(5, 1).clue: Ancient Greek scientist Praxogoras wrongly thought these carried air, as they were empty in corpses

(6, 1).clue: According to the popular rhyme, the total number of whacks used by Lizzie Borden on her parents

(1, 2).clue: Leaving for Italy in 218 B.C., he gave command of the Carthaginian army in Spain to his brother Hasdrubal

(2, 2).clue: Lucy had some splainin' to do after she & Ethel tore apart the newly built brick barbecue searching for this

(3, 2).clue: Also called comino, it's used in seed form or ground into powder to flavor a myriad of dishes

(4, 2).clue: He worked for Al Capone & was the FBI's Public Enemy No. 1

(5, 2).clue: At Cambridge, Wordsworth saw a statue of this scientist, "with his prism and silent face"

(6, 2).clue: Not just a baker's, it's also the number of a devil's dozen

(1, 3).clue: This future conqueror of the Incas was Balboa's second in command

(2, 3).clue: Of the "Lucy's Italian Movie" episode, Lucy said that "stepping on" these "was like stepping on eyeballs"

(3, 3).clue: It's a scientific fact: your egg whites will beat higher in a bowl made of this metal prized by chefs

(4, 3).clue: He was a captain by 1779, the year he turned 21

(5, 3).clue: Galileo famously saw spots before his eyes when he studied this in 1611

(6, 3).clue: Beware!  In a 1953 film classic there are this many "Fingers of Dr. T"!

(1, 4).clue: Name of the woman who became a widow on the Ides of March, 44 B.C.

(2, 4).clue: It was Ricky's signature tune & later the name of his club

(3, 4).clue: Craig Claiborne insisted that this Southern dish of pig intestines be served with vinegar & hot red pepper sauce

(4, 4).clue: It's no joke, this composer won an Oscar for his score of "The Great Gatsby"

(5, 4).clue: In 1924 Louis Victor de Broglie described the wave-like properties of this basic particle of an atom

(6, 4).clue: A quorum in the House of Representatives is this minimum number, a simple majority of the members

(1, 5).clue: In 1930 this French statesman whose name is linked with Kellogg called for a European union

(2, 5).clue: During a trip to Hollywood, Lucy has a run-in with William Holden at this famous restaurant

(3, 5).clue: This type of bouillon used to poach fish sounds like something a judge would serve

(4, 5).clue: Before Lou Reed, "A Walk on the Wild Side" was the title of a 1956 novel by this man

(5, 5).clue: The buckminsterfullerine is a giant molecule of this that resembles a geodesic dome or a soccer ball

(6, 5).clue: The scientific notation for this real number is 23 x 106

(2, 1).clue: We wonder "how does it feel" for him to be on his own with the No. 1 song "Like A Rolling Stone"

(3, 1).clue: The world's largest building by volume is this company's main assembly building in Everett, Washington

(4, 1).clue: It was fought in the Ardennes Forest in December 1944, & by dieters everyday

(5, 1).clue: In bowling, it's a split of the 8 & 10 pins; it's also a city in Ohio

(6, 1).clue: This story of the Hollywood film industry really was F. Scott Fitzgerald's "Last" novel--he didn't live to finish it

(2, 2).clue: In the '60s Little Eva had to make up a dance to go along with this song, No. 350

(3, 2).clue: These fliers are the U.S. Navy's equivalent to the RAF's Red Arrows

(4, 2).clue: In the King James Bible, it's the full name of the book that immediately follows the Gospels

(5, 2).clue: Dial (302) 739-3073 & you can get information on how to do this in Delaware

(6, 2).clue: This Bronte sister published "The Tenant of Wildfell Hall" in June 1848; she fell ill with tuberculosis & died in May 1849

(2, 3).clue: The most recent song on the list, at No. 180, is this duo's "Hey Ya!"

(3, 3).clue: One of the world's largest military aviation museums is located at this Air Force base near Dayton, Ohio

(4, 3).clue: Future president James Polk held this congressional post from 1835 to 1839

(5, 3).clue: Sartorial term for a policeman who doesn't wear a uniform while on duty

(6, 3).clue: It's a "Mystery" how this novel would have ended; Dickens died having only completed the first half

(2, 4).clue: No. 89 is this 1966 hit that John Phillips came up with on a cold winter's night in Manhattan

(3, 4).clue: In 1952 this airline's De Havilland Comets became the first jet passenger planes put into commercial service

(4, 4).clue: In 1993 this musical netted 7 Tonys, including one for Chita Rivera

(5, 4).clue: One of the laws of this 1969 book states that people are promoted until they reach their level of incompetence

(6, 4).clue: She died before completing her last novel, "The Buccaneers", set in the 1870s like "The Age of Innocence"

(2, 5).clue: And finally... their 1976 hit with "More Than A Feeling" just made the list at No. 500

(3, 5).clue: On October 4, 2004 this private craft won the $10 million Ansari X Prize by reaching space for the 2nd time within a week

(4, 5).clue: They're the personal bodyguard of the British monarch, though their duties are ceremonial

(5, 5).clue: This saint started his own society, & a charitable society founded in Paris in 1833 was also named for him

(6, 5).clue: This writer was working on a novel, "Le Premier Homme", when he was killed in a car accident

(0, 0).clue: This woman received the third-highest vote total of any candidate for all of the November 2004 elections
